newsitem.title: FRANCE: French doctors strike to go on, government firm.
newsitem.headline: French doctors strike to go on, government firm.

text.p: French junior hospital doctors vowed on Saturday to continue into next week a 17-day-old strike over the government's disputed plan to cap costs in the health service, a spokesman for the strikers said.
"We are determined, and we are calling for the protest to be toughened," the spokesman said. He said the strikers agreed at a meeting the stoppage would go on until at least Tuesday.
Six surgeons' unions have come out in support of the strike, saying on Friday evening they would join it next Thursday.
The junior doctors, on strike in 22 of the country's 26 teaching hospitals, are demanding the scrapping of automatic fines on doctors in regions which exceed government health spending targets.
The government looked no less determined to go ahead with the reform, which is part of its drive to bring down the welfare deficit and help France qualify for a single European currency in 1999.
It appeared to put the seal on the provisions disputed by the strikers by having them published on Saturday in the Official Gazette.
The provisions were agreed between the national health insurance fund and two health professionals' trade unions which support the reform.
Social Affairs Minister Jacques Barrot has said the measure was essential as a safeguard against overspending until new standard medical procedures take root.
